scribe_as_recorded: Muḥammad ibn Salāmah ibn ʻAbd al-Khāliq
scribe_as_recorded_agr: محمد بن سلامة بن عبد الخالق
physical_description: Extent: 15, 9 leaves : paper ; 164-181 x 115-124 (130-135 x 80-85) mm. bound to 182 x 127 mm.
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from text (fol. 1a, first group).|Marginal notes. In the introduction of the Qaṣīdah the copyist gives a brief account of the Wahhābī movement and how it was defeated by Muḥammad ʻAlī Pāshā of Egypt. He declares that he wrote this and will also follow it with rebuttals to the learned men who oppose it.|Collation: Paper ; 15 + 9 + (1) ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 17-19 lines per page ; ruled.|Description: Verse separators in red ; rubricated ; overlining of lines from Nūnīyah in red ; watermarks (first group: shield with a face-in-the-moon, roman-alphabet letters "AG"; second group: bird, fleur-de-lis, roman-alphabet letters "G&A"?) ; MS in fair condition.|Origin: Copied 20 or 26 Jumādá II? 1280 by Muḥammad ibn Salāmah ibn ʻAbd al-Khāliq (fol. 15a, first group).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, A.D. 1900.

scribe_as_recorded: Ibn al-Asīr, Yūsuf ibn ʻAbd al-Qādir, 1816 or 1817-1889 or 1890
scribe_as_recorded_agr: ابن الاسير، يوسف بن عبد القادر، 1816 or 1817-1889 or 1890
physical_description: Extent: 70 leaves : paper ; 182 x 138 (150 x 120) mm. bound to 182 x 142 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 70 + xxiv ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; MS in good condition.|Layout: 16-18 lines per page.|Marginal notes. On the title page (fol. 1a) occur several verses of poetry and a statement about the works in the volume. On the title page of the 2nd work (fol. 12a) is a statement in Latin copied from Casiri (Casiri 338) about four books of which ours is the last. Fol. 65a-70a the copyist wrote several verses of poetry, some wise sayings and several proverbs. Following this are 23 blank folios; on the folio following are a statement about the kinds of writing and two proverbs.|Ms. codex.|Origin: Kitāb al-Mubhij According to colophon copied 17 Muḥarram 1274 by Yūsuf ibn ʻAbd al-Qādir al-Asīr (fol. 11b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

scribe_as_recorded: Ḥalabī, Muḥammad, active 19th century
scribe_as_recorded_agr: حلبي، محمد، active 19th century
physical_description: Extent: 203, (1) leaves : paper ; 214 x 150 (70 x 100-110) mm. bound to 210 x 170 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 203 + (1) ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Decoration: Illuminated headpiece (fol. 1b) consisting of two large roundels in orange and black.|Description: Rubricated ; watermarks (shield, laurel leaves) ; MS in fair condition with some worm damage.|Layout: 22-24 lines per page ; frame-ruled in red.|Marginal notes. On the title page are two shahādahs. After the colophon and on the four following folios are several poems of poetry in praise of this book and the party for whom it was copied, evidently a vizir and a descendant of the prophet; following this are several verses of poetry by various authors and a medical prescription. On the three following folios is a brief medical treatise by Muḥammad ibn Yūsuf al-Sanūsī, 892 1486/7. On the two following folios are a charm, a verse of the Burdah and other writing. On the inside of the front and back covers are the autograph of a reader, the shahādah and other writing.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied Monday 24 Ṣafar 1229 by Muḥammad al-Ḥalabī in Burj, ʻAkkār (fol.195b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Obliterated autograph of an owner on title page. On folio 203b are two reading statements dated 1279 1862/3. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Collation: Paper ; fol. (1) + 150 + (1) ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Text in red and commentary in black ; some headings in yellow ; watermarks (roman-alphabet letters "EAC", shield with a face-in-the-moon) ; MS in good condition.|Layout: 15-25 lines per page, ruled.|Ms. composite codex.|On the folio before title page is a list of the names of the works contained in the MS. physical_description: Extent: i, 124, i leaves : paper ; 181 x 106 (131 x 56) mm. bound to 180 x 113 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from rubric on fol. 1a.|A few marginal notes (see fol. 103b and 118b). The last folio repeats with some changes the previous fol., in such a manner that there are two slightly different colophons for this copy. Several inscriptions and short excerpts from the Ṣiḥāḥ of Ismāʻīl ibn Ḥammād Jawharī (d. 1003?) on fol. 1a. Inscription in pencil in Roman script: "W-ll. 1152" on fol. (i)a (see Houtsma, M. Catalogue, 1886).|Collation: Paper ; fol. (1) + 124 + (1) ; catchwords ; foliated in ink using Hindu-Arabic numerals ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 17 lines per page ; ruled.|Description: Written in small naskh with elements of nastaʻlīq in black ink ; rubricated ; watermarks.|Decoration: The text is framed within gilt and black and red fillets on fol. 1b-3a, gold and black on fol. 3b-5a, one single black fillet on fol. 5b-11a and 111a-115a.|Colophon 1 (fol. 123a): copied by ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muṣṭafá al-mudarris al-Darāmuwī?, on Monday 12 Jumādá al-Ūlá 1072. Colophon 2 (fol. 124a): copied on Monday 12 Jumādá al-Ūlá 1072, followed by a note in Ottoman Turkish by the same hand giving the name of the copyist as Nāʼibʹzādah ʻAbd Allāh. This might be the same as the ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muṣṭafá (d. 1079/1668) mentioned in ʻUlamā Dimashq wa-aʻyānuhā fī al-qarn al-ḥādī ʻashar (1421/2000), vol. 2, p. 341.|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900, from the books of Amīn ibn al-Ḥasan al-Ḥulwānī al-Madanī al-Ḥanafī (Medina).

note: Ms. codex.|Title by a later hand on tail of text block (the same title appears on fol. 1a). The name of the author appears at the end of the text (fol. 94b). Marginal annotations apparently by another hand. Notes on small pices of paper pasted between the original leaves (see between fol. 6 and 7). Fol. 1 consists of a later endleaf with mention of the title pasted on the recto of an original fol. Inscriptions on the original fol. visible, including a title and kabīkaj. Fol. 95 consists of a later endleaf pasted on the verso of an original fol. Several inscriptions on the original fol. visible by transparency.|Collation: Paper; fol. ii + 95 + i; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 17 lines per page.|Description: Rubricated ; the entries are repeated on the margins in red ink.|Paper: Light cream paper with laid and chain lines visible.|On fol. 95a: Note mentioning the names of the six "Kutub al-uṣūl fī aḥādīth al-Rasūl."|On the margins of fol. 94b-95a: Several inscriptions mentioning dates of birth; one inscription in Ottoman Turkish.|Origin: Copy completed on a Thursday in the beginning of Dhū al-Ḥijjah 918 Feb. 1513 by ʻAlī ibn Khalīl al-Ḥanafī (colophon, fol. 94b).|From the books of Aḥmad ibn Muḥammad ibn Khalīl (original fol. 1a). physical_description: Extent: i, 219, i leaves : paper ; 245 x 170 (145 x 110) mm bound to 245 x 175 mm
note: Ms. composite codex.|Title from preamble (fol. 2b, l. 3).|Marginal and interlinear annotations, apparently by the same hand as the main text. Several small slips of paper with annotations inserted between folios. Fol. 1 and 219 are later additions in European paper with watermark, with inscriptions, including verses of poetry and short definitions. Fol. 2 consists of a leaf of similar paper pasted on the recto of an original folio. Fol. 218 consists of a leaf of similar paper pasted on the verso of an original fol. Inscriptions by another hand on fol. 218a, including the verses "raqqa al-zujāj wa-raqqat al-khamr ... ". On fol. 1b-2a, short text, apparently in the same hand as the inscriptions on fol. 1a, 218a and 219b. Inscription "450" in black ink, using Western numerals, on the pastedown of the upper cover (corresponds to Brill's list ; see Houtsma, M. Th. Catalogue d'une collection de manuscrits arabes et turcs, no. 432).|Collation: paper, fol. i, 219, i ; i (free endpaper) 1⁸ (+1, before the first fol. of the quire, in European paper with inscriptions ; -1, original fist fol. of the quire) 2-26⁸ 27⁸ (+1 ; +1 European paper) i (free endpaper) ; the quires are numbered using Arabic numerals in the form "al-thālith" (see fol. 17a) ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 15-34 lines per page.|Description: Written in casual thick taʻlīq or casual small thick naskh in black ink ; reference marks, overlining, re-inking and text-stops (teardrops, in groups of three) in red ink.|Paper: Thick soft cream paper, glossy, with laid and chain lines and pulp visible.|Origin: Īḍāḥ Copy completed in Baldat Qar/z--? Hitti reads Quraym by Ibrāhīm ibn Yūsuf on Yawm al-Jumʻah 1 ("fī ghurrah") Shaʻbān 762 June 1361 (colophon, fol. 213a). Statement on the margin of the colophon, indicating that this book was read in front of ʻAlā al-Dīn al-Sukhūmī, dated Qar/z--, on a Thursday at the end of Jumādá al-Ākhar 763 April 1362 -- Ajwibat copy completed at the end of Rabīʻ al-Ākhar 745 Sept. 1344 in Bukhārā (end of text, fol. 218a).|Partly erased ownership statement on the margin of fol. 2b, in the name of Muṣṭafá ibn Ibrāhīm, known as ...? Acquired by Robert Garrett from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Ms. codex.|Title from fol. 2a (1a in the modern foliation in pencil).|Ḥāshiyah on the margins (particularly on the beginning of the text) and on slips of paper pasted between the original folios. Several inscriptions in Arabic and Ottoman Turkish, including a note mentioning a court case, in the courthouse of Maḥmūd Bey, regarding the theft of the manuscript by Muṣṭafá Kār, and his imprisonment and subsequent death in captivity. Prayer in Arabic on fol. 2a.|Collation: Paper, fol. 248 ; 1¹⁰ (+ 1 at the beginning of quire) 2-24¹⁰ 25⁶ (+1 at the end of quire) ; the last word of the verso is repeated on the next recto ; foliation in red ink using Hindu-Arabic numerals ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 19 lines per page.|Description: Rubricated ; overlining and marginal keywords in red ; watermarks .|Origin: Copy completed in on the last day of Rabīʻ al-Awwal 1010/Sept. 28, 1601 by Muḥammad ibn Muṣṭafá (colophon, fol. 247b, followed by verses of poetry in Arabic).|Several ownership statements on the pastedown of the upper cover and on fol. 2a, some erased, one in the name of ʻAbd Allāh Mudarrisʹzādah Aqshahrī, with impression of a stamp dated 1231/1815 or 16. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

scribe_as_recorded_agr: جيدي، برهان بن عالم, active 14th century
physical_description: Extent: ii, 231, ii leaves : paper ; 265 x 175 (145 x 95) mm. bound to 265 x 185 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from tail of text block (later hand).|Annotations and commentaries on the margin, between the lines of the main text, and on pieces of paper pasted between the leaves. Several inscriptions and short texts, including verses of poetry, on fol. 1a. Kabīkaj (invocation against bookworms) on fol. 229a. Inscription "49" in Western numerals on the pastedown of the upper cover.|Collation: Paper ; fol. ii + 231 + ii ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 11 lines per page.|Description: Rubricated; overlining and other use of red; partially vocalized; wear with loss of a few words on the first leaves.|Paper: Thick cream paper, glossy, with laid lines and pulp visible.|Origin: According to colophon, copy completed on the eighth night of Shawwāl 727 by Burhān ibn ʻĀlam ibn Jamāl al-Dīn ibn ʻAbd al-Raḥmān al-Jaydī (fol. 228b).|Ownership statement in the name of Nūqādī Zade al-Sayyid Aḥmad Nūrī ibn Aḥmad al-Nūqādī, dated 1281 H. 1864 or 5 on fol. 1a. Partly erased ownership statement on fol. 228b, stating that the manuscript was bought at the al-Sūq al-Sulṭānī in Dhū al-Ḥijjah ---? in Qusṭanṭinīyah. Acquired from Brill, Leiden, 1900.

note: Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Inscription in Western numerals in black ink on the upper cover: "822". Drawing sketch representing some organ on fol. 48b.|Collation: Paper, fol. i, 48, i ; i (free endpaper) 1¹⁰ (+1 at beginning of quire) 2-4¹⁰ 5⁸ (-1 at the end of the quire) i (free endpaper) ; catchword on the verso of each leaf.|Layout: 21 lines per page ; frame-ruled in red.|Description: Written in medium small script in black ink ; rubricated ; watermarks.|Decoration: Elaborate headpiece (ʻunwān) on fol. 2b, executed in gold, orange, blue, green, and in black ink. physical_description: Extent: i, 240, i leaves: paper ; 260 x 180 (195 x 125) mm. bound to 260 x 180 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a). The end of the line, apparently bearing the date of composition of the text, is obliterated. The same title appears in the colophon (fol. 240a) and on the tail of the textblock.|Some marginal annotations, mainly collation notes. Several inscriptions on fol. 1a, including ownership statements and a collational note. Verses of poetry in Persian by a later hand on fol. 240b.|Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 240 + i ; catchwords ; quinions ; collation notes.|Layout: 29 lines per page.|Description: Written in medium small square script in black ink ; rubricated ; light cream paper, glossy, with laid and chain lines visible.|Decoration: Frame-ruled in gold, black and blue and large dots in gold for text-stops on fol. 1b-2a. The basmalah is written in gold in a cartouche defined by lines in gold outlined in black and a running pattern of crosses and dots on fol. 1b.|Several ownership statements on fol. 1a, including one in the name of Madyan al-ṭabīb dated 993 H., with impression of his seal and mention of the prize; of Muṣṭafá ibn Muḥammad ibn Aḥmad al-ṭabīb al-awwal bi-māristān sulṭān Aḥmad Khān, dated '137; of Muṣṭafá ibn Masʻūd, dated '213. Acquired by Robert Garrett from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Ms. codex.|Title from inscription on fol.1a (later hand).|Several inscriptions on fol. (1)-(4)b and 1a, including titles, prayers, and ownership statements. On fol. Kabīkaj (invocation against bookworms) on fol. 1a.|Collation: Paper ; fol. 4, 157 ; catchwords ; chiefly quinions ; collational note on fol. 1a mentioning the number of quires (juzʼ) as being 16 ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 29 lines per page.|Description: Written in 4 mm. script in black ink with use of red. scribe_as_recorded_agr: واعظ، محمد بن سلامة
physical_description: Extent: 77 leaves : paper ; 235 x 162 (160 x 95) mm. bound to x 242 x 173 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. ii + 77 + iii ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Text in red and commentary in black ; MS in good condition.|Layout: 21 lines per page.|Marginal notes and glosses. On title page are a charm and a Coptic calendar. After colophon is a note stating that this copy was compared with others belonging to ʻAbd al-Hādī Mūsá, a proof reader in Būlāq Printing Press, 1300 (1882/83) and found to be in exact agreement. On folio after colophon are several poems on love.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied al-Aḥad 12 Dhū al-Ḥijjah 1276 by Muḥammad ibn Salāmah ibn ʻAbd al-Khāliq al-Shāfiʻī surnamed al-Wāʻiẓ (fol. 76b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a)|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

subject_as_recorded: Ibn Durayd, Muḥammad ibn al-Ḥasan, 837 or 838-933. Maqṣūrah|Maqṣūrah (Ibn Durayd, Muḥammad ibn al-Ḥasan)|Manuscripts, Arabic--New Jersey--Princeton

physical_description: Extent: 41 leaves : paper ; 182 x 129 (145 x 95) mm bound to 184 x 129 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Marginal notes in red and black in different hands. On title page are eight verses of poetry. After the colophon are several quotations from the Qurʼān and a few wisdom verses. On the page following are ten verses by Abū Nuwās and a masʼalah on inheritance. The author of this commentary was a disciple of the famous grammarian Ibn Khālawayh (317-370/929-989/1), from whom he learned the ode.|Collation: Paper ; fol. 41 ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 16-18 lines per page.|Description: Text commented upon in bolder script ; some use of red ; MS in good condition.|Origin: According to colophon copy completed 684 (fol. 41a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

scribe_as_recorded: Sakhāwī, ʻAlī ibn Tāj al-Dīn, active 17th century
scribe_as_recorded_agr: سخاوي، علي بن تاج الدين، active 17th century
physical_description: Extent: 259 leaves : paper ; 182 x 129 (125 x 80) mm bound to 182 x 132 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Marginal notes and glosses in black and red. The elegy on folios 26 and 27, composed on the death of al-Malik al-Ẓāhir Abū al-Fatḥ Ghāzī, Ṣalāḥ al-Dīnʼs (Saladin) son, appears in Ibn Khallikān, Wafayāt (1299 AH), I, pp. 135-7. MS begins with statement that the poetical works of the author were collected and arranged by his friend and admirer Ḥasan ibn Muḥammad al-Qaylawī, because the author paid little attention to the collection of his works. MS is of very special historical importance in study of Ayyūbid period.|Collation: Paper ; fol. 259 ; catchwords ; partially foliated in ink using Hindu-Arabic numerals ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 17 lines per page with separation between hemistitches ; frame-ruled in red.|Description: Rubricated ; watermarks (coat-of-arms with roman-alphabet countermark "BB" with clover in between) ; MS in fair condition, some damage affecting legibility.|Decoration: Title page all in red ink with circle and frame line drawing. Illuminated headpiece of red, blue, white, pink, green, blue and gold in a floral design on fol. 1b.|Origin: According to colophon copied Wednesday illegible 1099 by ʻAlī ibn Tāj al-Dīn al-Sakhāwī (fol. 258b).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 309 + ii ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; both pastedowns and the leaf opposite striated with brown ink ; MS in good condition.|Layout: 17-18 lines per page ; partially frame-ruled in red.|Marginal notes and glosses. Folio preceding title page, which is mended, has a table of necrology. On page preceding title page is a statement about Jarīr as the best poet in Islam with some of his verses. On folio after colophon are several verses by unknown authors. The dīwān is of special historical value because in it the author recites military exploits of his ancestors in war against the Qarmaṭians of al-Baḥrayn during fifth and sixth Muslim centuries.|Ms. codex.|Title from text (fol. 2b).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

physical_description: Extent: 60 leaves : paper ; 174 x 130 (130 x 90) mm bound to 174 x 136 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from collective title page (fol. 1a).|Marginal notes by a later hand on folio 44. On folio 17a is a ʻʻtree of poetryʼʼ entitled "The Tree Comprising the Rising Stars." It contains the names of the Prophet and his Companions. Folio 28, on which the second poem begins, has been marked by a later hand with a blue silk thread stitched into it. The dates of composition of both poems are mentioned in the last verses of each, the first being 860 1456 and the second 857 1453. Both were first written in the enclosure around the Kaʻbah. Page immediately after the colophon has a number of medical prescriptions for poisoned wounds and information on the use of banj (bhang).|Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 60 ; catchwords ; watermarks (later endpapers only) ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 11 lines per page.|Description: Written in alternating black and red ink ; vowel signs ; MS in good condition, some pages mended. Folio 1 appears to be a replacement.|Ownership signatures: Muḥammad ibn Muṣṭafá dated 1039, ʻAbd al-ʻĀdil? Makkī al-Ṭūṭī? dated 1251 (fol. 1a). Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

On the title page are four verses of poetry by a transcriber, Ramaḍān al-ʻAṭīfī. On four folios before the title page is an index of the names in the MS; following is a statement to the effect that MS was written at the request and at the expense of Aḥmad Wihbi Wahbah, a bookseller in Ḥalab. He also collated the MS himself.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied Thursday 19 Muḥarram 1305 by Muḥammad ʻAbd al-ʻAzīz ibn/al-Mardīn Muḥammad Rāghib (fol. 321a).|Title from title page (fol. 5a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Rashīdī, ʻAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Muḥammad, active 14th century
author_as_recorded_agr: رشيدي، عبد الرحمن بن محمد، 14th century
physical_description: Extent: (1), 108 leaves : paper ; 254 x 172 (185 x 120) mm. bound to 174 x 255 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. (1) + 108 + ii ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubicated ; verse separators and other use of red ; some headings and other words overwritten in red ink, possibly at a later time or by a different hand ; MS in poor condition with a number of repairs and some staining.|Layout: 17-19 lines per page.|Marginal notes and glosses in different hands. On title page is a statement showing the wisdom of the Prophetʼs having been born on a Monday in Rabīʻ I, a statement that the MS was written by the author himself. On page after colophon are a quotation of verse and prose ascribed to al-Shāfiʻī, another ascribed to Abū Zayd al-Bisṭāmī and eight verses of poetry entitled al-Mukhammas al-Laṭīf.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied 23 Jumādá al-Awwal 774 by the author (fol. 108b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Ownership signatures: Ibrāhīm ibn al-Raʼīs Muḥammad al-Zaman dated 1180, Muḥammad Ṣāliḥ ibn Ibrāhīm al-Raʼīs dated 1208 (fol. 1a). Under the colophon on the same page are two autographs of owners, one an Imām of a Madrasah. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Qīrāṭī, Ibrāhīm ibn ʻAbd Allāh, 1326-1379 or 1380
scribe_as_recorded: Mālikī, Muḥammad ibn Aḥmad, active 15th century
scribe_as_recorded_agr: مالكي، محمد بن احمد، active 15th century
physical_description: Extent: (4), 128, (1) leaves : paper ; 177 x 135 (125 x 95) mm bound to 177 x 142 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|Marginal notes and glosses in different hand. The work has been collected by Badr al-Dīn Muḥammad ibn Burhān al-Dīn Ibrāhīm ibn Muḥammad al-Subkī, whose name is mentioned on folios 4, 50 and 122. Title page and perhaps a few folios are missing. On the two folios after the colophon is an ode by Ismāʻīl ibn Abī Zakarīyā ibn ʻAbd Allāh al-Muqrī eulogizing al-Malik al-Ashraf Ismāʻīl ibn al-ʻAbbās. The five following folios have a number of letters labelled by a later hand as independent of the MS, but evidently they are by al-Qīrāṭī as well. One of the letters is addressed to Taqī al-Dīn al-Maqrīzī, the famous historian 1365-1442.|Collation: Paper ; fol. (4) + 128 + (1) ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 23 lines per page.|Description: Rubricated ; a few lightly pink-tinted folios ; MS in fair condition.|Origin: According to colophon copied Sunday 19 Ṣafar 835 by Muḥammad ibn Aḥmad ibn ʻUthmān ... al-Mālikī (fol. 122a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Ibn Ḥijjah al-Ḥamawī, Taqī al-Dīn Abū Bakr ibn ʻAlī, -1434
author_as_recorded_agr: ابن حجة الحموي، تقي الدين ابو بكر بن علي، 1434
physical_description: Extent: 8 leaves : paper ; 176 x 117 (115 x 80) mm. bound to 182 x 126 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. iv + 8 + iv ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; MS in poor condition ; folios 2, 4, 5 and 7 are foxed and mended with gauze.|Layout: 15 lines per page.|Marginal notes in different hands. The work was composed 797 (1394/95) in Maʻarrat al-Nuʻmān, where al-Ḥasan ibn ʻAlī ibn Muḥammad ibn Yaḥyá ibn Aḥmad ibn Muḥammad ibn Naṣr ibn Abī Bakr ʻAbd al-Razzāq ibn ʻAdb-al-Qādir al-Jīlānī, a descendant of the great Jīlānī, asked Ibn Ḥijjah to amplify the poem and showed him a previous amplification of the same poem by Ibn al-Ṣāḥib. Ibn Ḥijjah, not pleased with previous amplification, decided to have it appear side by side with his own in order to reveal the marked differences. Ironically he called the work Rashf al-Manhilayn, his own and that of Ibn al-Ṣāḥib. First paragraph of MS indicates that same man at whose request work was composed is also scribe to whom Ibn Ḥijjah dictated MS.|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a)|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Ibn al-Muqrī, Ismāʻīl ibn Abī Bakr, 1354-1433 or 1434
author_as_recorded_agr: ابن المقري، اسماعيل بن ابي بكر، 1354-1433 or 1434
scribe_as_recorded: Sammān, Muḥammad ibn ʻAbd al-Raḥmān
scribe_as_recorded_agr: سمان، محمد بن عبد الرحمن
physical_description: Extent: 213 leaves : paper ; 220 x 144 (150 x 88) mm. bound to 220 x 160 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 213 ; catchwords ; foliation in red in Hindu-Arabic numerals ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Decoration: Title page and first page illuminated. Title page frame-ruled with gold and blue. Title page includes a headpiece in gold, dark brown, light blue surrounding the author's name. The first page of the text has a gold headpiece with blue and white decoration and gold and blue frame-ruling. Folio 2a has gold and blue frame; subsequent folios have a blue single-line frame. Codex irregularly alternates between white, yellow, and red paper.|Description: Red, black and green headings throughout ; MS is rare ; MS in fair condition, many folios are worm-eaten with some mended.|Layout: 15 lines per page ; frame-ruled in blue ; verse separators in red or green.|Marginal notes. On folio 128 there is a ʻʻpoetical treeʼʼ in praise of al-Malik al-Nāṣir. MS of importance for the historical study of the Rasūlid period. The author occupied a teaching position in the Jihādīyah School at Taʻizz and in the Niẓāmīyah at Zabīd. He also acted as judge in the latter town.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied Tuesday 22 Shaʻbān 1000 by Muḥammad ibn ʻAbd al-Raḥmān al-Sammān (fol. 213b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Ownership statements on title page, including one from ʻAbd al-Malik ibn ʻAbd Allāh ʻAbd al-Shakīr? written in a decorative frame above the title. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 209 ; catchwords; quires signed 2-14 ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; verse separators in red ; MS in poor condition with text fully legible but extensive staining, warped pages, and partially detached and damaged binding.|Layout: 21 lines per page.|Marginal notes in different hands. Among the poets quoted in the first section are al-Tilimsānī (1213-1291), al-Bahāʼ Zuhayr (1258), Jamāl al-Dīn ibn Nubātah (1287-1366), Ṣafī al-Dīn al-Ḥillī (1278-1349), al-Arrajāni (1756), Ibn Zaydūn (1003-1070), Ibn al-Wardī (1290-1349), Ibn al-Muʻtazz (861-908) and others. Geometric designs and writing on pastedowns, including the name of the Prophet and the rāshidūn Caliphs.|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Ownership signatures on the title page, some obliterated, include Muṣṭafá ibn Ḥasan al-Ṣaḥāwī al-Ḥanafī, Muṣṭafá ibn Ḥusayn ibn Kamāl al-Dīn al-Ḥusaynī dated 1087, and Zayn al-Dīn al-Shaṭ... al-Madanī. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

physical_description: Extent: 79 leaves : paper ; 202 x 143 (150 x 87) mm. bound to 202 x 150 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 79 ; catchwords ; foliated in black ink using Hindu-Arabic numerals ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Decoration: Simple illuminated headpiece on fol. 1b with gilt frame.|Description: Rubricated ; poems are numbered ; MS in good condition but several folios worm-eaten and mended. Probably a folio after the first is lost; the folios are numbered 84, while they count only 79. It is evident that some folios are lost at the end.|Layout: 21 lines per page with separation between hemistitches ; ruled.|Marginal notes; marginal and interlinear glosses. On the title page are defaced autographs of several owners, two verses of poetry and some additional markings.|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Abū al-Mawāhib, Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad, -1627 or 1628
author_as_recorded_agr: ابو المواهب، محمد بن محمد، -1627 or 1628
physical_description: Extent: 127 leaves : paper ; 231 x 145 (185 x 95) mm. bound to 228 x 158 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 127 ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Decoration: Illuminated headpiece in gold with floral drawing and a gilt roundel on fol. 1b. Fol. 2a frame-ruled in gold.|Description: Readings in red ; MS in poor condition, worm-eaten and foxed, loose folios and binding. MS is extremely rare.|Layout: 15 lines per page ; frame-ruled in red.|Ms. codex.|Though full name of author does not appear in MS, study of persons mentioned reveals that he lived in eleventh Muslim century; and in eulogizing the Prophet he designates himself as Abū al-Mawāhib ibn Ṣiddīq. Probably this copy was made during lifetime of author.|Title from heading (fol. 2b).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

scribe_label: ʻAbd Allāh ibn ʻAbd Allāh Udkāwī
physical_description: Extent: 43 leaves : paper ; 201 x 137 (140 x 95) mm. bound to 210 x 145 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 43 + i ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Headings and line markers in red ; MS in good condition but several folios are worm-eaten and mended.|Layout: 19 lines per page with separation between hemistitches.|Marginal notes. On folio 38 is a statement by a later hand that the dīwān ends there. On last five folios are several poems by the author, not included in the dīwān, and by others. On title page occur a numerical table, and some additional writing, most of which is defaced.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied Thursday 15 Rabīʻ II 1125 by ʻAbd Allāh ibn ʻAbd Allāh ibn Salāmah al-Muʼadhdhin al-Udkāwī (fol. 43b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Autographs (Provenance)|Title page carries autographs of several owners, mostly defaced, one of whom is ʻAlī, Nāʼib al-Ḥaram, and another which is dated 1223 (fol. 1a). Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Collation: Paper ; fols. i + 99 + i ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Vowel signs ; green flyleaves glued to initial and final folios of text block ; illegible title on lower edge of MS ; MS in good condition, paper cover is badly worn.|Layout: 15-25 lines per page ; ruled.|Marginal glosses. On page after colophon and on three following folios are a number of odes by the author not included in the dīwān, all bearing the date 1026 1617.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied Wednesday 27 Shawwāl 1027 (fol. 96a).|Title from title page (fol. 1a)|Ownership signatures: Aḥmad al-Iṣbaḥī 1256, Ḥusayn al-Wafāʼī 1150, name obscured 1232 (fol. 1a). Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 39 + i ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; MS in good condition.|Layout: 23 lines per page ; frame-ruled in red.|Ms. codex.|On the page following the colophon is a charm. This appears to be the third dīwān missing from Princeton's Islamic Manuscripts, Garrett no. 80H which carries the same ownership signatures.|Title from title page (fol. 2a).|On title page are two autographs of owners: Jaʻfar Muḥyī al-Qādirī dated 1219, and ʻAlī, Nāʼib al-Ḥaram dated 1263. author_as_recorded: Shabrāwī, ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muḥammad, 1680 or 1681-1757 or 1758
author_as_recorded_agr: شبراوي، عبد الله بن محمد، 1680 or 1681-1757 or 1758
physical_description: Extent: (1), 51 leaves : paper ; 212 x 143 (158 x 90) mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. (1) + 51 ; catchwords ; foliated in ink using Hindu-Arabic numerals ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Written in fair naskhi ; vowel signs ; rubrication and other important text in red ; MS in fair condition but several folios are worm-eaten.|Layout: 19 lines per page ; frame-ruled in red with separation between hemistitches ; fols. 1 and 2 frame-ruled in green and red.|Marginal notes. On the title page occur several verses of poetry and a statement that ʻAbd al-Muḥsin Sunbul made an amplification (tashṭīr) of the dīwān. After the colophon occur a statement that ʻAbd al-Muḥsin Sunbul, mentioned before, made an amplification (tashṭīr) and some corrections; two verses of poetry written by ʻAbd Allāh ibn Muḥammad Asʻad; and some verses of poetry on two other folios.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied Sunday 3 Rabī II 1178 by Muḥammad al-Khiḍr ibn Ibrāhīm al-Rashīdī (fol. 49b).|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Title page has several obscured autographs of owners, dated 1185 and 1187 and a seal impression reading: Min al-mawlīyah Ibn al-Shadāyid ibn Yaḥyá ʻAbduh ʻAlī al-Anṣārī ʻAbbās al-Khazrajī 1186. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

(1) + 136 + (1) ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; MS in good condition.|In the introduction the author explains this special type of poetry and states that putting stories and events into verse is very natural to the Persian tongue and is called Mathnawi, but that it is natural neither to the Arabic nor the Indian tongues. The book is divided into seven divisions, each called a daftar. On folio 131 and the five following folios are a short biography of the author and the story of the composition of the book. On the title page is a statement that the book was bought for 60 piasters.|Layout: 19 lines per page ; frame-ruled in red with separation between hemistitches.|Ms. codex.|Title from label on case.|Autograph of an owner, Muḥammad Shawqī Afandī, and his seal impression (fol. 1a). On folio 164 is a poem by ʻAlī ibn Muḥammad al-ʻĪsá written on a chess-board and readable only by following the movement of the ʻʻknightʼʼ in the game. Title page has a statement that the poetical works of ʻAbd al-Raḥmān ibn Yaḥyá al-Ānisī were originally compiled by his son Muḥammed, and on folio 53 we learn that the son died before the father.|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

author_as_recorded: Karāmah, Buṭrus ibn Ibrāhīm, 1774 or 1775-1850 or 1851
author_as_recorded_agr: كرامة، بطرس بن ابراهيم، 1774 or 1775-1850 or 1851
physical_description: Extent: 8 leaves : paper ; 210 x 150 (195 x 130) mm. bound to 210 x 155 mm.
note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 8 ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Written in naskhi ; MS in good condition, cover worm-eaten.|In the introduction the author states that he composed his first ode with the rhyme khāl in response to the suggestion of a Turkish poet who composed a Turkish ode with the same rhyme. The author composed his ode and sent it to Dāwūd Pāshā, former governor of Baghdād, who sent it to some poets in Baghdād; one of these sent an ode rhyming in rāʼ criticising Buṭrus Karāmahʼs ode because he was a Christian. The author composed his second ode rhyming in rāʼ in answer to that criticism. On the two folios after the colophon is a fragment on music by al-ʻAṭṭār ʻAlī. On the two following folios occurs an ode in eulogy of Abū al-Mawāhib al-Bakrī al-Ṣiddīqī, 1037 1627/8 by ʻAbd al-Raḥmān al-Mallāḥ.|Layout: 18-20 lines per page with separation between hemistitches.|Ms. codex.|Title supplied by cataloger.|On the title page occurs an obliterated seal impression. Seal impression that reads: bi-al-yumn ... Salāmah on fol. 5a. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

Volume 1: On the four folios before the title page occur a table of contents; 11 verses of poetry by Ḥasanayn Muḥammad, dated 1301 1884; and a short biography of the author. On the title page are three verses of poetry and the autograph and seal impression of the copyist, Muṣṭafá ibn Muḥammad al-ʻAfīfī 1279 1862/3. Volume 2: On the page after the colophon of Vol. III, on the two following folios and on the page before the beginning of Vol. IV occur several medical prescriptions, a verse of poetry and instructions for strengthening the paper of Qurʼāns by applying alum solution.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to title page copied 1282 by Muṣṭafá ibn Muḥammad ibn Sulaymān al-ʻAfīfī (vol. 1, fol. 5a).|Title from title page (vol. 1, fol. 5a).|On the title page of volume 2 are several autographs of readers and an owner with his seal impression, and a waqf statement dated 1137 1724/25 by Muḥammad ibn Khalīl ibn Ibrāhīm al-Diyārbakrī that he had dedicated this volume and the ones before to God, not to be owned nor sold nor given away nor pawned. Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Collation: Paper ; fol. 179 ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Decoration: Illuminated gilt headpiece. Fol. 1b and 2a are frame-ruled in double gold lines.|Description: Rubricated ; MS contains some red, green and yellow paper ; watermarks (grapes, design incorporating a heart) ; MS in good condition but several folios are worm-eaten and mended.|Layout: 13-32 lines per page.|Marginal notes and glosses. After the colophon are six verses of poetry, and an amplification (takhmīs) by the shaykh ʻAbd al-Ghanī. scribe_label: Ḥasan ibn Abī ʻAbd Allāh Azdī
physical_description: Extent: 3 volumes (206, 186, 200 leaves) : paper ; 255 x 170 (203 x 123) mm bound to 254 x 168 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from title page of volume 1 (fol. 1a).|Marginal notes and glosses; marginal summaries. On title page of vol. I occurs a brief account of the author's life and his works. On the folio before the title page of vol. I are 18 verses of poetry in praise of the book by the author. On the inside of the front cover of vol. I is a statement in Latin about other copies of the same work. Volume 3 is in a different hand and binding; called "sifr al-thānī" on the title page, it is labeled "al-mujallad al-thālith" on the edge of the text block. Circular design drawn on fol. 186b of volume 2. Following the colophon in volume 3 is the short text Ikhtiṣār al-qawl by Abū Muḥammad Makkī ibn Abī Ṭālib al-Qaysī.|Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 206 + i, i + 186 + i, ii + 200 + i ; catchwords (volumes 1-2) ; foliation in ink using Hindu-Arabic numerals (volume 1) ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: Volumes I and II, 19 lines per page; volume Ill, 25 lines per page|Description: Headings in black and red ; vowel signs ; MS in good condition but several folios are worm-eaten and mended.|Origin: Volume 3 copied 11 Rabīʻ al-Akhir 634 by Ḥasan ibn Abī ʻAbd Allāh ibn Ṣadaqah al-Azdī al-Ṣaflī in Damascus.|Ownership signatures: ? ibn Rustum ibn Aḥmad ibn Maḥmūd al-Shirwanī (vol. 1, fol. 2a and vol. 2, fol. 1a); Sharaf (vol. 1, fol. 2a); Abū Makram? Rustum al-Shīrwānī, Saʻdān ibn ʻIsá, Aḥmad ibn Muḥammad ibn Muslim, ʻUmar ibn ʻAbd al-Wahhāb ibn Ibrāhīm ... al-Qādirī (vol. 3, fol. 1a) Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

On a folio after the colophon is a statement about the Prophet, his virtues and his work.|Ms. codex.|Origin: According to colophon copied 1162 by Aḥmad ibn Muḥammad al-Arīḥāwī, known as Shāriḥ al-Kanz (vol. 2, fol. 326a).|Title from title page (vol. 1, fol. 1a).|The title page of both volumes have the ownership signature of Muḥammad ibn Saʻīd ibn al-Sharīf Surūr, other obscured ownership signatures and a seal impression. In the colophon the copyist states that the copy from which MS was made had no beginning and that he supplied it for the present copy. Evidently the first three folios do not belong to the book. On folio 1 appears the beginning which was supplied by the copyist; on folios 2 and 3, a prayer of 40 lines containing the 99 names of God, the title of a book, al-Zahr al-fāyiḥ min waṣf man tanazzahā ʻan al-dhunūb wa-al-qabāyiḥ, by Muḥammad ibn Aḥmad al-Sāyiḥ, and sayings by ʻAlī ibn Abī Ṭālib and Ibn ʻAṭāʼ Allāh.|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 1a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

note: Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 163 + ii ; catchwords ; quires signed 2-15 ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Description: Rubricated ; vowel signs ; watermarks (three crescents) ; MS in good condition. MS is rare.|Layout: 21 lines per page.|Marginal notes and glosses; marginal summaries in red. On the folios before the title page occur a table of contents (fol. 1b-5b), a statement about the author, another that this copy was written by the author himself (fol. 7a) and a summary of the contents (fol. 10a). Title page has several additions and some erasures. There is also a paragraph about the birth of Fāṭimah bint Muḥammad ibn Nāṣib al-Dīn Muḥammad on 3 Rajab 943 in Ḥalab with an addendum on her death on 10 Dhū al-Ḥijjah 950. The three folios after the colophon have an essay and a poem.|Ms. codex.|Title from title page (fol. 11a).|Ownership signatures include: Shaykhʹzādah (fol. 7a), Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad ibn Muḥammad al-Shawṭī, Mawlā Bā al-Saʻadī Ḥalabī, Sulaymān together with his seal impression, and Mīr Ḥasan al-Zuhdī ibn Khalīl Bāshā and his seal impression reading "fa-tabāraka Allāh aḥsan al-khāliqīn" (fol. 11a). Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.

physical_description: Extent: 3 volumes (481, 296, 339) leaves : paper ; 210-223 x 160 (155-170 x 97-130) mm bound to 215-219 x 165-180 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from title page (vol. 1, fol. 1a).|Marginal and interlinear notes and glosses. After the colophon there is a statement that the fourth volume was completed from the copy in the Khedivial Library, Cairo, though the three present volumes contain the whole work. It is stated in the preface that the author in composing his work depended on many commentaries, especially that of Ibn Faraḥ al-Qurṭubī, 671 1272/3. Volume 3 has label on spine.|Collation: Paper ; fol. (1), 481, 296, (1), 339 ; first 10 quires of volume one signed (1-10) ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 19-25 lines per page.|Description: Rubricated ; MS is in different hands and on different kinds of paper ; fols. 1-93 in volume 1, and 329-332, 335-338 in volume 3 are later replacements ; watermarks (v. 1, 1-93: roman-alphabet letters "BG", shield with a face-in-the-moon, "Andrea Galvani, Pordenone"; v. 1, fol. 94-481 and v. 2: three crescents; v. 3: crown-star-crescent; v. 3 replacement leaves: shield with a face-in-the-moon, "Andrea Galvani, Pordenone") ; volumes 1-2 in good condition, volume 3 in fair condition with loose pages.|Origin: According to colophons: volume 1 copied Sunday 12 Dhū al-Ḥijjah 1175 (fol. 481a), volume 2 copied Sunday 5 Jumādá al-Thānī 1185 by Yūsuf al-Ṭabbākh ibn Aḥmad al-Ṭabbākh (fol. 296a).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, A D. 1900.

physical_description: Extent: 120 leaves : paper ; 210 x 152 (160 x 105) mm bound to 208 x 160 mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Title from text (fol. 2b).|Marginal notes and glosses. Inscriptions on preliminary leaf (names of officials circa 1742) and folio 1a (names and a short sermon). Several fawāʼid immediately after colophon and on seven following folios; several are dated 1154 or 1155. They include: a short prayer/sermon; explication of hadith; short text captioned: Maʻná al-ḥifẓ hunā an yunquluhā ilá al-Muslimīn; text about a hadith of ʻAbd Allāh ibn ʻAbbās; text beginning: istaghfar Allāh, istaghfar Allāh, istaghfar Allāh al-ʻaẓīm, dated 1154; Ḥikāyah Ibrāhīm Adʹham; and Sharḥ Kāfiyah of al-Iṣfihīdī?.|Collation: Paper ; fol. i + 120 ; catchwords ; modern foliation in pencil using Western numerals.|Layout: 23 lines per page.|Description: Rubricated ; watermarks (crown-star-crescent; three crescents) ; MS in good condition.|Origin: According to colophon copied Thursday 4 Dhū al-Qaʻdah 1067 by Muṣṭafá ibn ʻAlī ibn Muḥammad al-Mālikī (fol. 113b).|Acquired from Brill, Leyden, 1900.
